prior_works.title: Asymptotically Efficient Adaptive Allocation Rules
prior_works.role: Foundational lower bound and consistency theory
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the instance-dependent lower bounds and notion of consistency that the paper leverages to calibrate instance-dependent regret rates (β) and prove optimality of the proposed tail-decay trade-offs.

prior_works.title: Finite-Time Analysis of the Multiarmed Bandit Problem
prior_works.authors: P. Auer, N. Cesa-Bianchi, P. Fischer
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces UCB with finite-time and high-probability guarantees, supplying techniques and benchmarks for relating expected regret to tail probabilities that the paper refines into sharp tail-risk characterizations.

prior_works.title: Minimax Policies for Adversarial and Stochastic Bandits
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes minimax-optimal worst-case regret via MOSS and highlights its tension with instance-dependent performance, directly motivating the paper’s explicit trade-off between worst-case optimality (α) and instance-dependent consistency (β).

prior_works.title: UCB Revisited: Improved Regret Bounds for the Stochastic Multi-Armed Bandit Problem
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Develops tighter high-probability and refined finite-time analyses of UCB-type policies, informing the paper’s precise linkage between the order of expected regret and the decay rate of large-regret tail probabilities.

prior_works.title: The KL-UCB Algorithm for Bounded Stochastic Bandits and Beyond
prior_works.role: KL-based confidence bounds and exponential tails
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces KL-UCB with Chernoff-style deviation control, a core technique the paper builds on to obtain exponential tail decay with only polynomial prefactors while meeting instance-dependent and worst-case targets.

prior_works.title: Optimally Confident UCB: Improved Regret for Finite-Armed Bandits
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows how tuning confidence radii can simultaneously optimize worst-case and instance-dependent regret up to constants, a design principle the paper generalizes into a tunable (α, β) policy achieving tail-optimal guarantees.

prior_works.title: Stochastic Multi-Armed Bandit Problem with Nonstationary Rewards
prior_works.authors: O. Besbes, Y. Gur, A. Zeevi
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the variation-budget framework and regret baselines for non-stationary rewards, which the paper extends by carrying its tail-risk characterization and trade-off policy to a non-stationary setting.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—characterizing the precise interplay between worst-case optimality, instance-dependent consistency, and light-tailed risk, and proposing a policy that achieves any target (α, β) while attaining optimal regret-tail decay—rests on three pillars from prior work. First, Lai and Robbins established the instance-dependent lower bounds and consistency paradigm that define what it means to be distribution-dependent optimal. Second, the UCB lineage (Auer et al.; Auer and Ortner) provided finite-time and high-probability analyses linking expected regret to deviation probabilities, setting methodological templates for controlling regret tails. Third, KL-based and carefully tuned confidence policies (Garivier and Cappé’s KL-UCB; Lattimore’s OCUCB) demonstrated how sharper, information-theoretic confidence radii yield exponential-type deviations and can simultaneously balance worst-case and instance-dependent performance.

Audibert and Bubeck’s MOSS clarified the minimax frontier and exposed tension with instance-dependent optimality, directly motivating a calibrated trade-off rather than a single operating point. Building on these insights, the paper formalizes how the order of expected regret dictates achievable tail decay and designs a policy whose confidence structure interpolates between minimax and instance-dependent regimes while preserving exponential tail behavior with only polynomial prefactors—proving this rate is unimprovable. Finally, the non-stationary extension leverages the Besbes–Gur–Zeevi framework to transplant these guarantees beyond the stationary setting, showing that the proposed tail-optimal trade-offs persist under controlled reward drift.
